duelGrammarTips.authText: To play duels, please log in or register.
duelGrammarTips.tipOne: Verb goes in 2nd position: Ich **lerne** Deutsch.
duelGrammarTips.tipTwo: Place or time at the beginning? Verb is still 2nd: **Heute** gehe ich.
duelGrammarTips.tipThree: Yes/No question: verb in 1st place ‚Äî **Kommst** du?
duelGrammarTips.tipFour: Subordinate clause: verb at the end ‚Äî ‚Ä¶weil ich **arbeite**.
duelGrammarTips.tipFive: Conjunction **und** does not change word order: Ich lerne und ich **spiele**.

examIndexPage.hint: We use an automatic speech recognition system. Speak clearly near the microphone.
examIndexPage.choice: Choose a level and start practicing all modules:

nominativ.rule: There are almost no special prepositions for the nominative. This case is usually used for the subject and after the verbs sein / werden / bleiben.
nominativ.tipOne: Nominative answers the questions Wer? / Was?
nominativ.tipTwo: After sein, werden, bleiben ‚Äî the predicate noun is in the nominative.
nominativ.tipThree: If there is a preposition, it is almost never nominative.
nominativ.practiceDescription: Identify the uses of nominative without prepositions.

akkusativ.rule: These prepositions always require the accusative: durch, f√ºr, gegen, ohne, um, bis, and also entlang (often as a postposition).
akkusativ.tipOne: Hack: F√úR, UM, DURCH, GEGEN, OHNE, (BIS), ENTLANG.
akkusativ.tipTwo: Movement 'to where' is often expressed with the accusative.
akkusativ.tipThree: bis is usually without article: bis Montag, bis Berlin.
akkusativ.tipFour: entlang ‚Äî as a postposition: den Fluss entlang.
akkusativ.translateOne: We are walking through the park.
akkusativ.practiceDescription: Practice the prepositions that require the accusative.

dativ.rule: These prepositions always require the dative: aus, au√üer, bei, mit, nach, seit, von, zu, gegen√ºber.
dativ.tipOne: Basic set: bei, mit, nach, seit, von, zu.
dativ.tipTwo: The state 'where?' is often expressed with the dative.
dativ.tipThree: gegen√ºber can stand after the noun: dem Haus gegen√ºber.
dativ.translateOne: He comes out of the house.
dativ.translateTwo: There was no one except the child.
dativ.translateSix: I have been learning German for a year.
dativ.translateSeven: The train leaves from the station.
dativ.translateNine: Opposite the house is a park.
dativ.practiceDescription: Review the prepositions that require the dative.

genitiv.rule: These prepositions require the genitive: statt, trotz, w√§hrend, wegen, au√üerhalb, innerhalb, jenseits/diesseits, aufgrund.
genitiv.tipOne: In spoken German, the genitive is often replaced by von + dative.
genitiv.tipTwo: Articles: des/eines; nouns often get the ending -s/-es.
genitiv.tipThree: Adjectives in the genitive get the ending -en.
genitiv.translateOne: Instead of sugar I take honey.
genitiv.translateTwo: Despite the rain, we go for a walk.
genitiv.translateThree: During the lesson the phone is off.
genitiv.translateFour: Because of the cold we stay at home.
genitiv.translateFive: Outside the city it is quieter.
genitiv.translateSix: Within a week you will get an answer.
genitiv.translateSeven: On the other side of the river is a village.
genitiv.translateEight: Due to roadworks the road is closed.
genitiv.practiceDescription: Practice the use of genitive prepositions.

adjectiveTheory.title: Adjectives in German: simple and clear
adjectiveTheory.subTitle: What they are, where they stand, how they are compared and which endings to use. At the end ‚Äî mini quiz.
adjectiveTheory.question: Question

adjectiveTheoryFirstBlock.title: 1) What is an adjective?
adjectiveTheoryFirstBlock.subtitlePartTwo: (Adjektiv) ‚Äî a word that answers the question 'what kind?'. Examples:
adjectiveTheoryFirstBlock.noteOnePartTwo: adjectives occur in two positions ‚Äî this determines whether endings are needed.

adjectiveTheorySecondBlock.title: 2) How to choose an ending: super short algorithm
adjectiveTheorySecondBlock.exampleThreePartTwo: In Akkusativ, Dativ and Genitiv almost always ending
adjectiveTheorySecondBlock.tipPartTwo: if in doubt in oblique cases (Akk/Dat/Gen) ‚Äî most often the ending

adjectiveTheoryThirdBlock.title: 3) Example: `ein` + adjective
adjectiveTheoryThirdBlock.paragraph: This is the most important topic for beginners. The article `ein` (one, some) does not always show the gender of the noun. In this case, the adjective takes over this function.
adjectiveTheoryThirdBlock.noteOnePartTwo: the adjective gets an ending that 'tells' us the gender of the noun, just like the definite article would do
adjectiveTheoryThirdBlock.exampleThreePartOne: The article `eine` already shows feminine, so the adjective only needs a simple ending
adjectiveTheoryThirdBlock.paragraphTwo: Let‚Äôs see how it works in sentences:
adjectiveTheoryThirdBlock.tableExampleOne: Examples in Nominativ (Who? What?) and Akkusativ (Whom? What?)
adjectiveTheoryThirdBlock.tipOnePartTwo: In Akkusativ masculine changes (`ein` ‚Üí `einen`), and the adjective almost always takes ending
adjectiveTheoryThirdBlock.tipOnePartThree: Feminine and neuter in Akkusativ look the same as in Nominativ.

adjectiveTheoryFourthBlock.title: 4) Mini tables for start
adjectiveTheoryFourthBlock.type: Idea of weak declension: in Nominativ singular often

verbsTheory.title: Verbs in German
verbsTheory.subTitle: Basics for a confident start: Pr√§sens, Perfekt, Pr√§teritum and Futur I. We cover word order and common mistakes.

verbTheoryFirstBlock.title: 1) Word order: verb in 2nd position
verbTheoryFirstBlock.subTitleSecondPart: ‚Äî is the change of a verb by persons and numbers (I do, you do...). In German it is the basis of a sentence.
verbTheoryFirstBlock.rulePartSecond: in a simple declarative sentence the conjugated verb
verbTheoryFirstBlock.rulePartThird: is always in the second position
verbTheoryFirstBlock.paragraphPartOne: If there is a second verb in the sentence (e.g. infinitive or Partizip II), it goes to the very

verbTheorySecondBlock.title: 2) Pr√§sens ‚Äî present tense
verbTheorySecondBlock.subTitle: The most common tense, used to describe actions in the present or future (with a time marker). Most verbs have the same endings.
verbTheorySecondBlock.paragraphPartTwo: In the 2nd and 3rd person singular (du, er/sie/es) the stem vowel often changes: f

verbTheoryThirdBlock.title: 3) Perfekt ‚Äî spoken past tense
verbTheoryThirdBlock.subTitle: Used for completed actions, especially in spoken language. Formula:

verbTheoryFourthBlock.title: 4) Pr√§teritum ‚Äî 'book' past tense
verbTheoryFourthBlock.subTitlePartOne: This tense is mostly found in books, news and stories. In spoken language it is mainly used for

verbTheoryFifthBlock.title: 5) Futur I ‚Äî future tense
verbTheoryFifthBlock.paragraph: Used to express plans or assumptions about the future. Formula:
verbTheoryFifthBlock.noteThreeSecondPart: in spoken German Pr√§sens is often used for the future if the context makes it clear (tomorrow, the day after tomorrow):

verbTheorySixthBlock.title: 6) Typical mistakes
verbTheorySixthBlock.typeOnePartSecond: Conjugated verb not in the second position.
verbTheorySixthBlock.typeTwoPartTwo: Second part of the verb (in Perfekt, Futur I) not at the end.

verbTheorySeventhBlock.questOne: How to say correctly: "I am learning German"?
verbTheorySeventhBlock.questTwo: Choose the correct word order: "Today I am going to the cinema".
verbTheorySeventhBlock.questThree: How will it be in Perfekt: "We did a lot"?
verbTheorySeventhBlock.questFour: Perfekt with a verb of motion: "He went home".
verbTheorySeventhBlock.questFive: Pr√§teritum of the verb "sein": "I was tired".
verbTheorySeventhBlock.questSeven: Choose the correct Partizip II of the verb "sehen" (to see).

idioms.title: Idioms and Phrases
idioms.subTitle: Understanding real language through fixed expressions
idioms.isFrazeologizm: ‚Äî a fixed combination of words whose meaning is not always clear from the individual words.
idioms.isIdiom: ‚Äî a type of phraseologism whose meaning cannot be understood literally. Like 'speaking in riddles' ‚Äî it means 'speaking unclearly', not about riddles.
idioms.explainFirstFrazeoligizm: to have a good head on one's shoulders
idioms.explainSecondIdiom: ‚Äî 'to tie a bear to someone' ‚Üí 'to pull someone‚Äôs leg'.

idiomFirstCategory.title: Everyday Expressions

idiomFirstCategory.fifthMeaning: Get up on the wrong side of the bed
idiomFirstCategory.SixthMeaning: Hit the nail on the head

idiomSecondCategory.title: Work and Study

idiomThirdCategory.title: Emotions and Behavior
idiomThirdCategory.secondMeaning: Have thick skin (not sensitive to criticism)
idiomThirdCategory.SixthMeaning: Say everything you think (without hiding emotions)

guessWord.article: Now try to guess the article of the word:

preposition.title: All About German Prepositions
preposition.guideTitle: Your complete guide to one of the most important grammar topics

prepositionsIntro.title: What is a Preposition
prepositionsIntro.paragraph: A preposition is a function word that shows the relationship between words in a sentence and helps form correct structure. It usually comes before a noun or pronoun it refers to. In German, a preposition almost always requires the noun to be in a specific case (Dative, Accusative, Genitive).

prepositionsFirstBlock.title: Basic Meanings of Prepositions
prepositionsFirstBlock.description: They answer the questions "where?" and "to where?".
prepositionsFirstBlock.translateSecondPart: (on, at, to ‚Äì vertical surfaces): Das Bild h√§ngt
prepositionsFirstBlock.translateThree: (The book is lying on the table.)
prepositionsFirstBlock.translateFirstPartTwo: (on ‚Äì for days of the week/times of day):
prepositionsFirstBlock.translateSecondPartTwo: (at ‚Äì for specific times): Der Film beginnt
prepositionsFirstBlock.translateThirdPartThree: (We‚Äôre going to the sea in summer.)

prepositionsSecondBlock.title: Merging Prepositions with Articles
prepositionsSecondBlock.paragraph: Germans love to shorten! Prepositions often merge with the following article. You need to know and actively use these forms.

prepositionsThirdBlock.title: Most Important: Prepositions by Case
prepositionsThirdBlock.paragraph: This is the most important classification. You simply need to memorize the case required by each preposition.
prepositionsThirdBlock.twoWayTranslateFirst: The car is parked in front of the house.
prepositionsThirdBlock.twoWayTranslateSecond: I‚Äôm parking the car in front of the house.
prepositionsThirdBlock.genitiveExample: (I read a lot during the vacation.)

adjectiveComparisonContentSide.ruleOne: To form the comparative (Komparativ), add -er. For the superlative (Superlativ), use the structure am + adjective + -sten.
adjectiveComparisonContentSide.ruleTwo: Many short adjectives with (a, o, u) in the stem take an umlaut (√§, √∂, √º) in comparative and superlative forms.
adjectiveComparisonContentSide.ruleThree: Some important adjectives and adverbs have unique comparison forms or change their stem. You need to memorize them.
adjectiveComparisonContentSide.firstThemeTipOne: 1. This is the basic rule and works for most adjectives.
adjectiveComparisonContentSide.firstThemeTipTwo: 2. Use the comparative to compare two items: Er ist schneller als ich (He is faster than me).
adjectiveComparisonContentSide.firstThemeTipThree: 3. The superlative with ‚Äúam‚Äù is used after a verb: Er l√§uft am schnellsten (He runs fastest of all).
adjectiveComparisonContentSide.firstThemeTipFour: 4. If the adjective stands before a noun, another form is used: der schnellste Mann (the fastest man).
adjectiveComparisonContentSide.practiceFirstDescription: Form comparative and superlative degrees for ordinary adjectives.
adjectiveComparisonContentSide.secondThemeTipOne: 1. This rule mainly covers monosyllabic adjectives.
adjectiveComparisonContentSide.secondThemeTipTwo: 2. Learn common ones: alt, gro√ü, jung, kalt, warm, lang, kurz.
adjectiveComparisonContentSide.secondThemeTipFour: 4. The adjective gesund follows this rule: gesund ‚Üí ges√ºnder ‚Üí am ges√ºndesten.
adjectiveComparisonContentSide.practiceSecondDescription: Choose the correct form for adjectives that take an umlaut.
adjectiveComparisonContentSide.thirdThemeTipOne: 1. These are exceptions‚Äîyou can‚Äôt derive them, you must learn them.
adjectiveComparisonContentSide.thirdThemeTipTwo: 2. gut, viel and gern are the most important and frequent exceptions.
adjectiveComparisonContentSide.thirdThemeTipThree: 3. Note how hoch and teuer lose a vowel in the stem for easier pronunciation.
adjectiveComparisonContentSide.practiceThirdDescription: Test how well you know exception adjectives.

adjectiveContentSide.ruleFirst: If an adjective follows a definite article (der, die, das), which already shows the gender and case, the adjective takes the ending -e or -en.
adjectiveContentSide.ruleSecond: If an adjective follows an indefinite article (ein, eine) or a possessive pronoun (mein, dein), which doesn't always clearly indicate the gender or case, the adjective 'helps' and takes the 'strong' ending.
adjectiveContentSide.ruleThird: If there is no article before the adjective, it must show gender and case on its own. So it takes endings similar to definite articles.
adjectiveContentSide.firstThemeTipOne: 1. This is 'weak' declension. The article already shows everything, and the adjective 'is lazy'.
adjectiveContentSide.firstThemeTipTwo: 2. In most cases, use -en. It‚Äôs the most common and safest ending.
adjectiveContentSide.firstThemeTipThree: 3. Exception: use -e only in 5 singular cases ‚Äî Nominative (der gute, die gute, das gute) and Accusative for feminine and neuter (die gute, das gute).
adjectiveContentSide.firstThemeTipFour: 4. Tip: if the article form is like in the Nominative (der, die, das), the ending is -e. If the article changes (den, dem, des), use -en.
adjectiveContentSide.FirstThemeTipTranslateThree: We are helping the young woman.
adjectiveContentSide.practiceFirstDescription: Test your knowledge of adjective endings after der, die, das.
adjectiveContentSide.secondThemeTipOne: 1. This is 'mixed' declension. First, check if the gender is clear from the article.
adjectiveContentSide.secondThemeTipTwo: 2. If the gender is UNCLEAR (Nominative masc. and neuter ‚Üí ein Mann, ein Kind), the adjective takes the 'strong' ending: -er for masculine, -es for neuter.
adjectiveContentSide.secondThemeTipThree: 3. This also applies to Accusative neuter (ein Kind).
adjectiveContentSide.secondThemeTipFour: In ALL OTHER cases, the endings are the same as in 'weak' declension (mostly -en).
adjectiveContentSide.secondThemeTipTranslateFour: He is talking to a nice person.
adjectiveContentSide.practiceSecondDescription: Test your knowledge of adjective endings after ein, eine, mein, kein.
adjectiveContentSide.thirdThemeTipOne: 1. This is 'strong' declension. The adjective carries all the meaning.
adjectiveContentSide.thirdThemeTipTwo: 2. Tip: the adjective ending usually matches the last letter of the definite articles (der, die, das...).
adjectiveContentSide.thirdThemeTipThree: 3. This also applies to Accusative neuter (ein Kind).
adjectiveContentSide.thirdThemeTipFour: 4. Example: Dative feminine ‚Üí article der ‚Üí ending -er (mit gutER Laune).
adjectiveContentSide.thirdThemeTipFifth: 5. Important exception: in Genitive masculine and neuter, the ending is -en (not -es) to avoid double 's'.
adjectiveContentSide.practiceThirdDescription: Test your knowledge of endings when there is no article before the adjective.

adjectiveBasicPageSideBar.title: Levels A1 - A2
adjectiveBasicPageSideBar.exampleThirdFeelings: He is always tired after work.

adjectiveBasicPracticeSide.title: Practice
adjectiveBasicPracticeSide.descriptionFirst: Test how well you know color names in German.
adjectiveBasicPracticeSide.descriptionSecond: Describe how people feel in different situations.
adjectiveBasicPracticeSide.descriptionThird: Describe people and objects using the correct adjectives.
adjectiveBasicPracticeSide.descriptionFifth: Describe objects by their size and shape.

verbTypeCategoryFirst.firstPart: To ask a question, structures are often used
verbTypeCategoryFirst.secondTip: These verbs are one of the most important topics for fluent B1-level communication.
verbTypeCategoryFirst.ruleContent: Some German verbs require a specific preposition and case. You should learn the combination 'verb + preposition + case' as one unit.
verbTypeCategoryFirst.firstExampleTranslate: I'm waiting for you. (warten auf + Akk)
verbTypeCategoryFirst.secondExampleTranslate: He thinks about his job. (denken an + Akk)
verbTypeCategoryFirst.thirdExampleTranslate: She speaks with the teacher. (sprechen mit + Dat)
verbTypeCategoryFirst.fourthExampleTranslate: I dream of a long journey. (tr√§umen von + Dat)
verbTypeCategoryFirst.practiceDescription: Choose the correct preposition for each verb.

verbTypeCategorySecond.thirdPart: is inserted between prefix and stem. For example:
verbTypeCategorySecond.ruleContent: In the present tense (Pr√§sens), the prefix is separated and goes to the end of the sentence. The main verb is conjugated in second position.
verbTypeCategorySecond.practiceDescription: Put the verb and prefix in the correct positions.

verbTypeCategoryThird.ruleContent: Strong verbs change their stem vowel in the 2nd and 3rd person singular (du, er/sie/es) in the present tense. You need to memorize their past forms.
verbTypeCategoryThird.secondExampleTranslate: He helps his mother in the garden.
verbTypeCategoryThird.practiceDescription: Choose the correct form of the strong verb.

verbTypeCategoryFourth.first: In Akkusativ case, the forms are:
verbTypeCategoryFourth.second: Some verbs are always reflexive (sich freuen), others can be reflexive (waschen / sich waschen).
verbTypeCategoryFourth.ruleContent: These verbs use the reflexive pronoun 'sich', which changes by person and number. It shows that the action is directed at oneself.

modalVerbsPage.title: Modal Verbs
modalVerbsPage.chooseLevel: Choose a level from the menu

modalGroupA.tipFirstA: 1. The modal verb is always in second position and is conjugated.
modalGroupA.tipSecondA: 2. The main verb goes to the end in the infinitive form.
modalGroupA.tipFourthA: 4. `ich` and `er/sie/es` forms are the same (ich kann, er kann).
modalGroupA.exampleTranslateThird: We want to go to the cinema.
modalGroupA.exampleTranslateFourth: I would like a coffee, please.

modalGroupBTips.tipOne: In a subordinate clause, the verb is at the end (e.g., weil ich m√ºde
modalGroupBTips.tipSeven: "als" + modal verb in the past tense: als ich nicht

subordinate–°lause.verbExampleOne: I'm going home because I'm tired.
subordinate–°lause.verbExampleTwo: I think that he won't come today.
subordinate–°lause.verbExampleThree: If I have time, I will help you.
subordinate–°lause.verbExampleFour: Although it's raining, we are going for a walk.
subordinate–°lause.verbExampleFive: I'm learning German in order to work in Germany.

error.title: Case No. 404: The Page Has Vanished!
error.subTitle: Detective, we need your help. The page disappeared, leaving behind only a few strange clues. Study them and help us find the way back.
error.label: Clues at the crime scene:
error.paperOne: A scrap of paper reads: "I went where verbs are always regular." Seems like a dead end.
error.paperTwo: A witness heard, that the Page speaking with a creepy accent, mixing up 'der' and 'die'. Very suspicious.
error.paperThree: The compass doesn‚Äôt point north but to the nearest library. Maybe the Page just wanted to read?
error.footerText: Hmm, this case is tricky... Should we drop it and return to HQ?

prasensTips.third: 3. Add an ending based on the subject (lern + e, st, t)
prasensTips.fourth: 4. This rule applies to all regular verbs.

perfectTips.first: 1. Important: 'haben' is used with actions, 'sein' with movement or state change
perfectTips.second: 2. Weak verbs: Partizip II = ge + stem + (e)t (e.g., gemacht, gelernt)
perfectTips.third: 3. Strong verbs: vowel change + -en ending (e.g., gesehen, gefahren)
perfectTips.fourth: 4. Separable prefix: ge goes inside (e.g., ankommen ‚Üí angekommen)
perfectTips.fifth: 5. Inseparable prefix (ver-, be-, etc.): no ge (e.g., versprechen ‚Üí versprochen)
perfectTips.sixth: 6. Auxiliary verb is conjugated; Partizip II goes to sentence end

prateritumTips.first: 1. Regular verbs: add endings -te, -test, -te, -ten, -tet, -ten to the stem
prateritumTips.third: 3. Irregular verbs: different stem (e.g., gehen ‚Üí ging, sehen ‚Üí sah)
prateritumTips.fourth: 4. Same endings used with the new stem
prateritumTips.fifth: 5. Unlike Perfekt, Partizip II and auxiliary verbs are not used

plusquamperfekt.first: 1. Plusquamperfekt = Pr√§teritum of haben/sein + Partizip II
plusquamperfekt.second: 2. Example: hatte gemacht, war gegangen, hatte gesehen
plusquamperfekt.third: 3. Use of haben/sein is the same as in Perfekt
plusquamperfekt.fourth: 4. Partizip II is formed as usual: ge + stem + (e)t or irregular form

rulesFirstBlock.title: Basic rules of German articles
rulesFirstBlock.subTitle: A short and clear cheat sheet for everyone who wants to use der, die, das correctly!
rulesFirstBlock.firstCardTitle: The article depends on the gender
rulesFirstBlock.remember: You almost always need to memorize the noun's gender along with the word!

rulesSecondBlock.firstCardSub: Regardless of the gender in singular, the plural always uses

rulesThirdBlock.firstCardSubTitle: German has 4 cases, and each gender has different article forms for each case.

rulesFourthBlock.firstCardSubTitle: German has 4 cases, and each gender has different article forms for each case.
rulesFourthBlock.exampleTime: Days of the week, months, seasons ‚Äî always masculine gender

rulesFifthBlock.exampleFirst: Always learn nouns with their article:

tensesPrasens.explain: Insert the verb in the correct form.

futurOne.tipOne: 1. The auxiliary verb werden is conjugated: ich werde, du wirst, er/sie/es wird, etc.
futurOne.tipTwo: 2. The main verb (infinitive) is placed at the end of the sentence
futurOne.tipFour: 4. Replaces Pr√§sens if you want to emphasize intention or make a prediction
futurOne.tipFive: 5. Example: Ich werde lernen. / Er wird bald kommen.
futurOne.tipSix: 6. Question sentence: Wirst du morgen kommen?
futurOne.howToDoExample: werden (Pr√§sens) + infinitive at the end of the sentence
futurOne.howToUseSecondExample: Assumptions about the present or future
futurOne.practiceDesc: Choose the correct form of werden and build Futur I.

pr√§teritum.howToDo: Strong verb stem with vowel change / weak stem + ‚Äú-te‚Äù
pr√§teritum.howToUseSecond: In spoken ‚Äî only with `haben`, `sein` and modal verbs
pr√§teritum.example: The princess lived in a castle.
pr√§teritum.exampleTwo: As a child I really loved to read.
pr√§teritum.explain: Write the correct verb form in Pr√§teritum.

pqPerfect.howToUseSecond: Shows that one event happened before another in the past.
pqPerfect.example: He had already eaten when I arrived.
pqPerfect.exampleTwo: After she finished work, she went home.

about.title: Bored of learning German and noun articles?
about.lead: Tired of memorizing flashcards, rewriting word lists and still forgetting articles?
about.whySecond: Battle with cards against other players
about.whyThird: Learn words in various game modes
about.whyFourth: Study the language in a fun, game-like way!
about.whyFifth: Build the word using the alphabet!
about.whyFooter: Try these methods and you‚Äôll see learning differently!

aboutList.one: Every new word isn‚Äôt just a checkmark ‚Äî it‚Äôs a step forward! Gain experience, unlock new levels, track your progress, and earn achievements.
aboutList.two: The achievement and reward system makes learning exciting: complete quests, discover secret badges, earn trophies, and collect rare rewards for your success in German.
aboutList.three: Don‚Äôt limit yourself to boring repetition: train your memory in different modes ‚Äî listen to audio, build words letter by letter, choose one method or try them all, and explore the language from multiple angles.
aboutList.four: Turn on game mode: build a word using the alphabet like magical runes! It‚Äôs not only fun but also improves attention and visual memory.
aboutList.five: In this mode, a random word is selected. The player guesses the word by choosing letters from the alphabet! You can try to guess early (number of attempts is limited to prevent brute-force). At the end, you must write the article of the guessed word.
aboutList.six: Spaced repetition helps reinforce knowledge: the system will remind you of the right words and run mini-tests, so you stay on top of your German game.

aboutAnimText.third: Do you want to change that?

footer.copy: Der Die Das. All rights reserved.

examples.label: Articles in German:
examples.title: Learn German articles easily and forever! Step-by-step theory with examples, rules, lifehacks, and instant practice.

examplesFirstBlock.title: What are articles?
examplesFirstBlock.subtext: Articles are accompanying words (der, die, das) that indicate gender, number, and case. In German, choosing the right article is critical for understanding and correct speech.

examplesSecondBlock.title: Types of articles
examplesSecondBlock.exampleTitle: Used when talking about something specific or already known.
examplesSecondBlock.exampleSecondTitle: Used when mentioning something for the first time or something non-specific.
examplesSecondBlock.exampleNotDefinite: Example: eine Katze schl√§ft. ‚Äî A (some) cat is sleeping.

exampleThirdBlock.label: How to use the indefinite article
exampleThirdBlock.subtext: The indefinite article (ein / eine / ein) agrees with the noun's gender:
exampleThirdBlock.important: Note: In the plural, the indefinite article is not used!

sessionLabels.articleWordFor: Enter the article and the word

choiceTheme.placeholder: Enter a German sentence or word with articles
